title: Build CRUD operations for contacts
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Master server actions, form handling, and database operations.

TASKS:
1. Create server actions for: createContact, updateContact, deleteContact, getContacts
2. Build a contacts list page with server-side rendering
3. Create a form to add new contacts (use shadcn Form components)
4. Implement edit functionality
5. Add delete with confirmation

LEARNING POINTS:
- Server Actions vs API routes - when to use each?
- Form validation (react-hook-form + zod)
- Optimistic updates
- Revalidation strategies

CHECKPOINT: You should have a fully functional contacts management system.

title: Implement activity/interaction tracking
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Work with timestamps, activity feeds, and audit logs.

TASKS:
1. Create interactions table (notes, calls, emails, meetings)
2. Build a form to log new interactions
3. Display interaction history for each contact
4. Add timestamps and auto-track created_by user
5. Implement an activity feed on dashboard

FEATURES TO CONSIDER:
- Different interaction types
- Rich text notes (simple textarea or markdown?)
- Filtering by interaction type
- Timeline visualization

CHECKPOINT: Users can log and view interaction history for contacts.

title: Add error handling, loading states, and polish
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Learn production-ready patterns and UX improvements.

TASKS:
1. Add proper error boundaries
2. Implement loading skeletons for all data fetching
3. Add toast notifications for actions (success/error)
4. Implement form validation with helpful error messages
5. Add empty states with helpful CTAs
6. Test error scenarios (network failures, invalid data)

UX PATTERNS TO IMPLEMENT:
- Suspense boundaries with loading.tsx
- error.tsx for error handling
- Optimistic UI updates
- Accessible forms and buttons

CHECKPOINT: The app should feel polished with clear feedback for all user actions.

title: Create dashboard with data visualization
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Learn data aggregation and client-side charting.

TASKS:
1. Create a dashboard page with key metrics
2. Write aggregation queries (count contacts, recent activities, etc.)
3. Install and use a charting library (recharts recommended)
4. Build 2-3 simple charts (bar, line, or pie)
5. Make the dashboard responsive

METRICS TO CONSIDER:
- Total contacts and growth over time
- Contacts by company
- Recent interactions
- Pipeline status (if you add deals)

CHECKPOINT: A functional dashboard showing meaningful CRM metrics.

title: Set up Zustand for client-side state management
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Understand client-side state management and when to use it vs server state.

TASKS:
1. Install zustand
2. Create your first store (e.g., UI state like sidebar open/closed)
3. Learn the difference between server state and client state
4. Implement a practical use case (modal state, filters, or theme)
5. Understand when to use Zustand vs React Context vs Server State

CONCEPTS TO EXPLORE:
- What is client state vs server state?
- When should you use Zustand vs useState?
- How does Zustand compare to Redux or Context API?
- Persist state to localStorage (optional)

PRACTICAL EXAMPLES TO TRY:
- Sidebar/navigation toggle state
- Filter selections (before they're applied)
- Modal/dialog open/closed state
- User preferences (theme, view mode)

CHECKPOINT: You have at least one working Zustand store managing UI state in your app.

NOTE: Don't use Zustand for data from your database - that's server state handled by Server Components and Actions.

title: Set up project environment variables and Neon database connection
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Understand environment configuration and database connection setup.

TASKS:
1. Create a Neon serverless PostgreSQL database (free tier)
2. Set up .env.local with database connection string
3. Install database client library (pg or @vercel/postgres recommended)
4. Create a simple test connection file to verify database connectivity
5. Document the connection pattern you chose and why

RESOURCES TO EXPLORE:
- Neon console (neon.tech)
- Next.js environment variables docs
- Connection pooling concepts

CHECKPOINT: You should be able to successfully connect to your database and log a test query result.

title: Implement data filtering, sorting, and search
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Learn complex data queries and UI state management.

TASKS:
1. Add search functionality to contacts list
2. Implement column sorting (name, email, date added)
3. Add filters (by company, by status, etc.)
4. Use URL search params to maintain filter state
5. Optimize queries with proper indexes

CONCEPTS TO EXPLORE:
- useSearchParams and useRouter
- SQL query optimization
- Debouncing search input
- Pagination vs infinite scroll

CHECKPOINT: Users should be able to search, filter, and sort their contacts efficiently.

title: Implement authentication with NextAuth.js
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Understand authentication flows and session management.

TASKS:
1. Install and configure NextAuth.js (v5/Auth.js recommended)
2. Set up at least one provider (credentials or OAuth)
3. Create sign-in and sign-up pages
4. Implement protected routes using middleware
5. Store user sessions and understand how they work

CONCEPTS TO EXPLORE:
- JWT vs session-based auth
- Middleware in Next.js App Router
- Password hashing (if using credentials)
- OAuth flow (if using providers)

CHECKPOINT: Users should be able to sign up, sign in, and access protected pages.

title: Set up Zod for form validation and type safety
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Master form validation, type inference, and error handling with Zod.

TASKS:
1. Install zod and @hookform/resolvers
2. Create a schemas directory for validation schemas
3. Build your first schema (e.g., contactSchema with name, email, phone validation)
4. Integrate Zod with react-hook-form
5. Implement custom error messages and validation rules
6. Learn about type inference from schemas

CONCEPTS TO EXPLORE:
- What is schema validation and why use it?
- How does Zod provide type safety?
- Client-side vs server-side validation (do both!)
- Refining schemas with custom validation logic
- Reusing schemas across client and server

PRACTICAL IMPLEMENTATIONS:
- Email format validation
- Phone number formatting
- Required vs optional fields
- String length limits
- Custom business logic validation

INTEGRATION POINTS:
- Use with react-hook-form on client
- Validate Server Action inputs on server
- Share schemas between client/server for type safety

CHECKPOINT: You have reusable Zod schemas integrated with forms, providing type-safe validation on both client and server.

RESOURCES:
- Zod documentation: https://zod.dev
- shadcn form components use Zod + react-hook-form
- Server Actions should always validate inputs with Zod

title: Add relationship management (contacts to companies)
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Handle complex data relationships and nested forms.

TASKS:
1. Create companies CRUD operations
2. Link contacts to companies (many-to-one relationship)
3. Build a company detail page showing all contacts
4. Add ability to assign/reassign contacts to companies
5. Implement cascade delete considerations

CHALLENGES:
- How do you handle a contact without a company?
- Should you use a select dropdown or autocomplete?
- What happens when a company is deleted?

CHECKPOINT: Contacts and companies should be properly linked with intuitive UI.

title: Initialize shadcn/ui and create base layout components
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Understand component libraries and Next.js layout patterns.

TASKS:
1. Install and configure shadcn/ui
2. Add your first components: Button, Card, Input, Label
3. Create a main layout component with navigation
4. Set up a basic responsive sidebar or header
5. Explore the generated component code to understand the patterns

QUESTIONS TO ANSWER:
- How does shadcn differ from other UI libraries?
- Where are the components stored and why?
- How does Tailwind integrate with shadcn?

CHECKPOINT: You should have a basic layout structure that you can reuse across pages.

title: Design and implement database schema for CRM
description:
LEARNING GOAL: Learn database schema design and migrations.

TASKS:
1. Design tables for: users, contacts, companies, interactions
2. Choose a migration tool (Drizzle ORM or Prisma recommended)
3. Write your first migration to create tables
4. Add relationships between tables (foreign keys)
5. Run the migration against your Neon database

DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS:
- What fields does a contact need?
- How do contacts relate to companies?
- How will you track interactions/activities?
- What indexes might improve performance?

CHECKPOINT: Your database should have a complete schema with proper relationships.
